pull_request.title: Add signature API (proposal)
pull_request.body:
Following discussion on pull request #14, here is a suggested API for signing. No scheme has been integrated yet. If the team agrees, I'll start work on integrating one.

One open question is what to do with stateful schemes, such as XMSS, that do not adhere with a conventional signature API. Since the main goal of OQS is to compare PQ schemes, it is useful to include them (like XMSS in pull request #79) even if there are limitations on usage of the private key. (NIST for example [suggests](http://csrc.nist.gov/groups/ST/post-quantum-crypto/faq.html#Q2) to define specific use cases for stateful schemes). One option is to not expose the state through the API, and simply return an error if the key is now unusable (this could be sufficient for comparison testing, but insecure for a real-application). The alternative would be to expose the state through the API (and that might still not be sufficient enough for security, to deal with state reset attacks). Thoughts?

repo.name: liboqs
repo.description: C library for quantum-safe cryptographic algorithms

repo.name: liboqs
repo.description: C library for quantum-resistant cryptographic algorithms.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,138 @@
+/**
+ * \file sig.h
+ * \brief Header defining the API for generic OQS Signature
+ */
+
+#ifndef __OQS_SIG_H
+#define __OQS_SIG_H
+
+#include <stddef.h>
+#include <stdint.h>
+
+#include <oqs/rand.h>
+
+enum OQS_SIG_alg_name {
+	OQS_SIG_alg_default,
+};
+
+typedef struct OQS_SIG OQS_SIG;
+
+/**
+ * OQS signature object
+ */
+typedef struct OQS_SIG {
+
+	/**
+	 * PRNG
+	 */
+	OQS_RAND *rand;
+
+	/**
+	 * Specifies the name of the sig method
+	 */
+	char *method_name;
+
+	/**
+	 * Classical security in terms of the number of bits provided by the
+	 * signature method.
+	 */
+	uint16_t estimated_classical_security;
+
+	/**
+	 *  Equivalent quantum security in terms of the number of bits provided by the
+	 *  signature method.
+	 */
+	uint16_t estimated_quantum_security;
+
+	/**
+	 *  Private key length.
+	 */
+	uint16_t priv_key_len;
+
+	/**
+	 *  Public key length.
+	 */
+	uint16_t pub_key_len;
+
+	/**
+	 *  Maximum signature length.
+	 */
+	uint16_t max_sig_len;
+
+	/**
+	 * Named parameters for this key exchange method instance, if any.
+	 */
+	char *named_parameters;
+
+	/**
+	 * Opaque pointer for passing around instance-specific data
+	 */
+	void *params;
+
+	/**
+	 * Opaque pointer for passing around any computation context
+	 */
+	void *ctx;
+
+	/**
+	 * Pointer to a function for public and private signature key generation.
+	 *
+	 * @param s                Signature structure
+	 * @param priv             The private key
+	 * @param pub              The public key
+	 * @return                 1 on success, or 0 on failure
+	 */
+	int (*keygen)(const OQS_SIG *s, uint8_t **priv, uint8_t **pub);
comment.body:
- Pass in OQS_RAND, not OQS_SIG.
- priv and pub should be uint8_t *, not uint8_t ** (i.e., up to the caller to provided memory, rather than callee to do a malloc)

@@ -0,0 +1,138 @@
+/**
+ * \file sig.h
+ * \brief Header defining the API for generic OQS Signature
+ */
+
+#ifndef __OQS_SIG_H
+#define __OQS_SIG_H
+
+#include <stddef.h>
+#include <stdint.h>
+
+#include <oqs/rand.h>
+
+enum OQS_SIG_alg_name {
+	OQS_SIG_alg_default,
+};
+
+typedef struct OQS_SIG OQS_SIG;
+
+/**
+ * OQS signature object
+ */
+typedef struct OQS_SIG {
+
+	/**
+	 * PRNG
+	 */
+	OQS_RAND *rand;
+
+	/**
+	 * Specifies the name of the sig method
+	 */
+	char *method_name;
+
+	/**
+	 * Classical security in terms of the number of bits provided by the
+	 * signature method.
+	 */
+	uint16_t estimated_classical_security;
+
+	/**
+	 *  Equivalent quantum security in terms of the number of bits provided by the
+	 *  signature method.
+	 */
+	uint16_t estimated_quantum_security;
+
+	/**
+	 *  Private key length.
+	 */
+	uint16_t priv_key_len;
+
+	/**
+	 *  Public key length.
+	 */
+	uint16_t pub_key_len;
+
+	/**
+	 *  Maximum signature length.
+	 */
+	uint16_t max_sig_len;
+
+	/**
+	 * Named parameters for this key exchange method instance, if any.
+	 */
+	char *named_parameters;
+
+	/**
+	 * Opaque pointer for passing around instance-specific data
+	 */
+	void *params;
+
+	/**
+	 * Opaque pointer for passing around any computation context
+	 */
+	void *ctx;
+
+	/**
+	 * Pointer to a function for public and private signature key generation.
+	 *
+	 * @param s                Signature structure
+	 * @param priv             The private key
+	 * @param pub              The public key
+	 * @return                 1 on success, or 0 on failure
+	 */
+	int (*keygen)(const OQS_SIG *s, uint8_t **priv, uint8_t **pub);
+
+	/**
+	 * Pointer to a function for signature generation.
+	 *
+	 * @param s                Signature structure
+	 * @param priv             The signer's private key
+	 * @param msg              The message to sign
+	 * @param msg_len          Length of the message to sign
+	 * @param sig              The generated signature
+	 * @param sig_len          Length of the generated signature
+	 * @return                 1 on success, or 0 on failure
+	 */
+	int (*sign)(const OQS_SIG *s, const uint8_t *priv, const uint8_t *msg, const size_t msg_len, uint8_t **sig, size_t *sig_len);
+
+	/**
+	 * Pointer to a function for signature verification.
+	 *
+	 * @param s                Signature structure
+	 * @param pub              The signer's public key
+	 * @param msg              The signed message
+	 * @param msg_len          Length of the signed message
+	 * @param sig              The signature to verify
+	 * @param sig_len          Length of the signature to verify
+	 * @return                 1 on success, or 0 on failure
+	 */
+	int (*verify)(const OQS_SIG *s, const uint8_t *pub, const uint8_t *msg, const size_t msg_len, const uint8_t *sig, const size_t sig_len);
+
+	/**
+	 * Pointer to a function for freeing the allocated signature structure
+	 *
+	 * @param s                Signature structure
+	 */
+	void (*free)(OQS_SIG *s);
+
+} OQS_SIG;
+
+/**
+ * Allocate a new signature object.
+ *
+ * @param rand               Random number generator.
+ * @param alg_name           Algorithm to be instantiated
+ * @param named_parameters   Name or description of method-specific parameters
+ *                           to use for this instance (as a NULL-terminated C string),
+ *                           if any, or NULL.
+ * @return                   The object on success, or NULL on failure.
+ */
+OQS_SIG *OQS_SIG_new(OQS_RAND *rand, enum OQS_SIG_alg_name alg_name, const char *named_parameters);
+int OQS_SIG_keygen(const OQS_SIG *s, uint8_t **priv, uint8_t **pub);
+int OQS_SIG_sign(const OQS_SIG *s, const uint8_t *priv, const uint8_t *msg, const size_t msg_len, uint8_t **sig, size_t *sig_len);
+int OQS_SIG_verify(const OQS_SIG *s, const uint8_t *pub, const uint8_t *msg, const size_t msg_len, const uint8_t *sig, const size_t sig_len);
+void OQS_SIG_free(OQS_SIG *s);

+	 * Pointer to a function for signature verification.

+/**

comment.body: OQS_SIG_keygen, OQS_SIG_sign, and OQS_SIG_verify should be updated in light of the comments above.  They should all take OQS_RAND as an input. These ones *should* take OQS_SIG as an input, since these ones will call the corresponding algorithm from the OQS_SIG structure.

Since the main goal of OQS is to compare PQ schemes, it is useful to include them (like XMSS in pull request #79) even if there are limitations on usage of the private key. (NIST for example [suggests](http://csrc.nist.gov/groups/ST/post-quantum-crypto/faq.html#Q2) to define specific use cases for stateful schemes). One option is to not expose the state through the API, and simply return an error if the key is now unusable (this could be sufficient for comparison testing, but insecure for a real-application). The alternative would be to expose the state through the API (and that might still not be sufficient enough for security, to deal with state reset attacks). Thoughts?

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,138 @@
+/**
+ * \file sig.h
+ * \brief Header defining the API for generic OQS Signature
+ */
+
+#ifndef __OQS_SIG_H
+#define __OQS_SIG_H
+
+#include <stddef.h>
+#include <stdint.h>
+
+#include <oqs/rand.h>
+
+enum OQS_SIG_alg_name {
+	OQS_SIG_alg_default,
+};
+
+typedef struct OQS_SIG OQS_SIG;
+
+/**
+ * OQS signature object
+ */
+typedef struct OQS_SIG {
+
+	/**
+	 * PRNG
+	 */
+	OQS_RAND *rand;
+
+	/**
+	 * Specifies the name of the sig method
+	 */
+	char *method_name;
+
+	/**
+	 * Classical security in terms of the number of bits provided by the
+	 * signature method.
+	 */
+	uint16_t estimated_classical_security;
+
+	/**
+	 *  Equivalent quantum security in terms of the number of bits provided by the
+	 *  signature method.
+	 */
+	uint16_t estimated_quantum_security;
+
+	/**
+	 *  Private key length.
+	 */
+	uint16_t priv_key_len;
+
+	/**
+	 *  Public key length.
+	 */
+	uint16_t pub_key_len;
+
+	/**
+	 *  Maximum signature length.
+	 */
+	uint16_t max_sig_len;
+
+	/**
+	 * Named parameters for this key exchange method instance, if any.
+	 */
+	char *named_parameters;
+
+	/**
+	 * Opaque pointer for passing around instance-specific data
+	 */
+	void *params;
+
+	/**
+	 * Opaque pointer for passing around any computation context
+	 */
+	void *ctx;
+
+	/**
+	 * Pointer to a function for public and private signature key generation.
+	 *
+	 * @param s                Signature structure
+	 * @param priv             The private key
+	 * @param pub              The public key
+	 * @return                 1 on success, or 0 on failure
+	 */
+	int (*keygen)(const OQS_SIG *s, uint8_t **priv, uint8_t **pub);
+
+	/**
+	 * Pointer to a function for signature generation.
+	 *
+	 * @param s                Signature structure
+	 * @param priv             The signer's private key
+	 * @param msg              The message to sign
+	 * @param msg_len          Length of the message to sign
+	 * @param sig              The generated signature
+	 * @param sig_len          Length of the generated signature
+	 * @return                 1 on success, or 0 on failure
+	 */
+	int (*sign)(const OQS_SIG *s, const uint8_t *priv, const uint8_t *msg, const size_t msg_len, uint8_t **sig, size_t *sig_len);
+
+	/**
+	 * Pointer to a function for signature verification.
+	 *
+	 * @param s                Signature structure
+	 * @param pub              The signer's public key
+	 * @param msg              The signed message
+	 * @param msg_len          Length of the signed message
+	 * @param sig              The signature to verify
+	 * @param sig_len          Length of the signature to verify
+	 * @return                 1 on success, or 0 on failure
+	 */
+	int (*verify)(const OQS_SIG *s, const uint8_t *pub, const uint8_t *msg, const size_t msg_len, const uint8_t *sig, const size_t sig_len);
+
+	/**
+	 * Pointer to a function for freeing the allocated signature structure
+	 *
+	 * @param s                Signature structure
+	 */
+	void (*free)(OQS_SIG *s);

pull_request.title: Add signature API (proposal)
pull_request.body:
Following discussion on pull request #14, here is a suggested API for signing. No scheme has been integrated yet. If the team agrees, I'll start work on integrating one.

One open question is what to do with stateful schemes, such as XMSS, that do not adhere with a conventional signature API. Since the main goal of OQS is to compare PQ schemes, it is useful to include them (like XMSS in pull request #79) even if there are limitations on usage of the private key. (NIST for example [suggests](http://csrc.nist.gov/groups/ST/post-quantum-crypto/faq.html#Q2) to define specific use cases for stateful schemes). One option is to not expose the state through the API, and simply return an error if the key is now unusable (this could be sufficient for comparison testing, but insecure for a real-application). The alternative would be to expose the state through the API (and that might still not be sufficient enough for security, to deal with state reset attacks). Thoughts?

+

+

+

+	 */
+	uint16_t max_sig_len;
+
+	/**
+	 * Named parameters for this key exchange method instance, if any.
+	 */
+	char *named_parameters;
+
+	/**

+	void *params;
+
+	/**
+	 * Opaque pointer for passing around any computation context

+	void *ctx;
+
+	/**
+	 * Pointer to a function for public and private signature key generation.
+	 *
+	 * @param s                Signature structure
+	 * @param priv             The private key
+	 * @param pub              The public key
+	 * @return                 1 on success, or 0 on failure
+	 */
+	int (*keygen)(const OQS_SIG *s, uint8_t **priv, uint8_t **pub);
+
+	/**
+	 * Pointer to a function for signature generation.
+	 *
+	 * @param s                Signature structure
+	 * @param priv             The signer's private key
+	 * @param msg              The message to sign
+	 * @param msg_len          Length of the message to sign
+	 * @param sig              The generated signature
+	 * @param sig_len          Length of the generated signature
+	 * @return                 1 on success, or 0 on failure
+	 */
+	int (*sign)(const OQS_SIG *s, const uint8_t *priv, const uint8_t *msg, const size_t msg_len, uint8_t **sig, size_t *sig_len);
+
+	/**
+	 * Pointer to a function for signature verification.
+	 *
+	 * @param s                Signature structure
+	 * @param pub              The signer's public key
+	 * @param msg              The signed message
+	 * @param msg_len          Length of the signed message
+	 * @param sig              The signature to verify
+	 * @param sig_len          Length of the signature to verify
+	 * @return                 1 on success, or 0 on failure
+	 */
+	int (*verify)(const OQS_SIG *s, const uint8_t *pub, const uint8_t *msg, const size_t msg_len, const uint8_t *sig, const size_t sig_len);
+
+	/**
+	 * Pointer to a function for freeing the allocated signature structure
+	 *
+	 * @param s                Signature structure
+	 */
+	void (*free)(OQS_SIG *s);
+
+} OQS_SIG;
+
+/**
+ * Allocate a new signature object.
+ *
+ * @param rand               Random number generator.
+ * @param alg_name           Algorithm to be instantiated
+ * @param named_parameters   Name or description of method-specific parameters
+ *                           to use for this instance (as a NULL-terminated C string),
+ *                           if any, or NULL.
+ * @return                   The object on success, or NULL on failure.
+ */
+OQS_SIG *OQS_SIG_new(OQS_RAND *rand, enum OQS_SIG_alg_name alg_name, const char *named_parameters);

@@ -0,0 +1,138 @@
+/**
+ * \file sig.h
+ * \brief Header defining the API for generic OQS Signature
+ */
+
+#ifndef __OQS_SIG_H
+#define __OQS_SIG_H
+
+#include <stddef.h>
+#include <stdint.h>
+
+#include <oqs/rand.h>
+
+enum OQS_SIG_alg_name {
+	OQS_SIG_alg_default,
+};
+
+typedef struct OQS_SIG OQS_SIG;
+
+/**
+ * OQS signature object
+ */
+typedef struct OQS_SIG {
+
+	/**
+	 * PRNG
+	 */
+	OQS_RAND *rand;
+
+	/**
+	 * Specifies the name of the sig method
+	 */
+	char *method_name;
+
+	/**
+	 * Classical security in terms of the number of bits provided by the
+	 * signature method.
+	 */
+	uint16_t estimated_classical_security;
+
+	/**
+	 *  Equivalent quantum security in terms of the number of bits provided by the
+	 *  signature method.
+	 */
+	uint16_t estimated_quantum_security;
+
+	/**
+	 *  Private key length.
+	 */
+	uint16_t priv_key_len;
+
+	/**
+	 *  Public key length.
+	 */
+	uint16_t pub_key_len;
+
+	/**
+	 *  Maximum signature length.
+	 */
+	uint16_t max_sig_len;
+
+	/**
+	 * Named parameters for this key exchange method instance, if any.
+	 */
+	char *named_parameters;
+
+	/**
+	 * Opaque pointer for passing around instance-specific data
+	 */
+	void *params;
+
+	/**
+	 * Opaque pointer for passing around any computation context
+	 */
+	void *ctx;
+
+	/**
+	 * Pointer to a function for public and private signature key generation.
+	 *
+	 * @param s                Signature structure
+	 * @param priv             The private key
+	 * @param pub              The public key
+	 * @return                 1 on success, or 0 on failure
+	 */
+	int (*keygen)(const OQS_SIG *s, uint8_t **priv, uint8_t **pub);
+
+	/**
+	 * Pointer to a function for signature generation.
+	 *
+	 * @param s                Signature structure
+	 * @param priv             The signer's private key
+	 * @param msg              The message to sign
+	 * @param msg_len          Length of the message to sign
+	 * @param sig              The generated signature
+	 * @param sig_len          Length of the generated signature
+	 * @return                 1 on success, or 0 on failure
+	 */
+	int (*sign)(const OQS_SIG *s, const uint8_t *priv, const uint8_t *msg, const size_t msg_len, uint8_t **sig, size_t *sig_len);
comment.body:
sig_len should be used by the caller to specify the length of sig, so that the sign function can ensure not to overflow sig. Keeping sig_len as an in-out parameter (size_t*) allows the signature function to return the number of bytes written to sig, keeping the return value of the sign function consistent with the other functions in this API (booleans). 

Aside -- in the documentation of sig_len, reference s.max_sig_len. Do you expect callers to always provide a buffer of length max_sig_len bytes?

(NIST for example [suggests](http://csrc.nist.gov/groups/ST/post-quantum-crypto/faq.html#Q2) to define specific use cases for stateful schemes). One option is to not expose the state through the API, and simply return an error if the key is now unusable (this could be sufficient for comparison testing, but insecure for a real-application). The alternative would be to expose the state through the API (and that might still not be sufficient enough for security, to deal with state reset attacks). Thoughts?

Since the main goal of OQS is to compare PQ schemes, it is useful to include them (like XMSS in pull request #79) even if there are limitations on usage of the private key. (NIST for example [suggests](http://csrc.nist.gov/groups/ST/post-quantum-crypto/faq.html#Q2) to define specific use cases for stateful schemes). One option is to not expose the state through the API, and simply return an error if the key is now unusable (this could be sufficient for comparison testing, but insecure for a real-application). The alternative would be to expose the state through the API (and that might still not be sufficient enough for security, to deal with state reset attacks). Thoughts?

repo.name: liboqs
repo.description: C library for quantum-safe cryptographic algorithms

repo.description: C library for quantum-resistant cryptographic algorithms.

+ * OQS signature object

+

+
+	/**
+	 * Specifies the name of the sig method
+	 */
+	char *method_name;
+
+	/**
+	 * Classical security in terms of the number of bits provided by the
+	 * signature method.
+	 */
+	uint16_t estimated_classical_security;
+
+	/**
+	 *  Equivalent quantum security in terms of the number of bits provided by the
+	 *  signature method.
+	 */
+	uint16_t estimated_quantum_security;
+
+	/**
+	 *  Private key length.
+	 */
+	uint16_t priv_key_len;
comment.body: Use size_t for lengths of buffers.  I'd also use it for the estimated_*_security members, but that's just preference.

pull_request.title: Add signature API (proposal)
pull_request.body:
Following discussion on pull request #14, here is a suggested API for signing. No scheme has been integrated yet. If the team agrees, I'll start work on integrating one.

One open question is what to do with stateful schemes, such as XMSS, that do not adhere with a conventional signature API. Since the main goal of OQS is to compare PQ schemes, it is useful to include them (like XMSS in pull request #79) even if there are limitations on usage of the private key. (NIST for example [suggests](http://csrc.nist.gov/groups/ST/post-quantum-crypto/faq.html#Q2) to define specific use cases for stateful schemes). One option is to not expose the state through the API, and simply return an error if the key is now unusable (this could be sufficient for comparison testing, but insecure for a real-application). The alternative would be to expose the state through the API (and that might still not be sufficient enough for security, to deal with state reset attacks). Thoughts?
